feed.title: Open Source and Reproducible MIR Research
feed.subtitle: The goal of this tutorial is to provide hands-on, practical training for MIR researchers to learn modern tools for improving the quality of their research software.

entry.title: Part 1: Installing Tools
entry.content:
Welcome! This part of the tutorial will cover installing the tools that you‚Äôll need to have on your laptop: the Python programming language, the Conda package manager, and the git version control system.

Install Python

Visit the main Python page, and download Python 3.6 or higher.

Mac users, you very probably have Python 2.7 on your computer ‚Äì please do go and get Python 3.6.

Linux users, you have some version of Python on your machine ‚Äì please make sure that you have Python 3.6, and go and get it if not.

Windows users, we highly recommend that you install the [Windows System for Linux][wsl-install] and Ubuntu. You can then do the rest of this tutorial as a Linux user! While you‚Äôre welcome to use Powershell, we can‚Äôt guarantee that we‚Äôll be able to help you!

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see:

(You‚Äôll see these checkpoints throughout the tutorial. If you‚Äôre doing the tutorial with us in person, we‚Äôll stop at these points to make sure that everyone is in the same place. If your checkpoint is working, you can put a blue sticky note on your laptop. If something‚Äôs not working, that‚Äôs totally OK! Put a red sticky note on your machine, and we‚Äôll come help.)

Install Conda

Conda is a package manager for Python code and lower-level code that supports Python. Anaconda is a version of Conda that comes with lots and lots of pre-installed packages for scientific computing. We‚Äôre going to use Anaconda so we don‚Äôt have to go digging for obscure Fortran and C libraries.

Visit the Anaconda website, and follow the steps for your platform.

Windows users, please use your Linux install, and install the Linux version!

Gotchas:

  • If you‚Äôre using zsh or another non-bash shell, you‚Äôll need to add things to your PATH yourself. We recommend moving the lines that the installer added from your .bash_profile file to your .zshrc file
  • If you‚Äôre using a virtualenv, you‚Äôll need to turn it off before installing Anaconda! Conda in general does not play well with virtualenvs.

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see:

Install git

git is a version control system ‚Äì it keeps track of changes that you make to your code. This makes it hard for you to lose changes that you have made, and makes it easy for you to return to a working version of your code. git in particular also makes it easy to collaborate with other folks.

Visit the git website, and follow the steps for your platform.

Linux users, you may already have git installed - please make sure that you‚Äôre on version 2.15 or or higher.

Windows users, please use your Linux install, and install the Linux version! (We‚Äôll stop reminding you about this soon, we promise.)

We recommend against using a graphical interface for git ‚Äì mostly because we won‚Äôt be able to help you with it in this tutorial!

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see:

Success!

We‚Äôve installed everything we‚Äôll need on our machines. In Part 2, we‚Äôll set up the various web apps and accounts that we‚Äôll need.
entry.summary: Welcome! This part of the tutorial will cover installing the tools that you‚Äôll need to have on your laptop: the Python programming language, the Conda package manager, and the git version control system.

entry.title: Part 2: Setting Up Services
entry.content:
Welcome to Part 2! In this section we‚Äôll set up accounts for the web services that we need ‚Äì GitHub, Travis CI, and ReadTheDocs.

Set Up GitHub

GitHub hosts your code, makes it easy for other folks to collaborate with you, and makes it easier for other web services to hook into your code

Vist GitHub, and create an account. Once you‚Äôve got an account, you need to create some SSH keys.

SSH keys are big numbers that GitHub uses for authorization. Setting them up can be a bit fincky, but we‚Äôll get through it!

First, create a new SSH key by following these steps ‚Äì make sure to pick the correct platform.

Now, we‚Äôll add the key to our GitHub account. The steps to do so are here ‚Äì again, make sure you pick the correct platform!

Finally, let‚Äôs verify that your key works! The steps are here.

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see:

Set Up Travis CI

Travis CI is a tool for ‚ÄúContinuous Integration‚Äù, which is just a fancy word for running the code that tests your software whenever you change your software. We won‚Äôt get to using Travis for a little bit, but let‚Äôs get the setup out of the way now.

Visit Travis, and make an account by pressing the Sign In With GitHub button.

You‚Äôll be asked to authorize Travis to use your Github account. Do so, and you‚Äôll get redirected to your profile screen. On your profile screen, press the ‚ÄúActivate‚Äù button to finish connecting Travis to you GitHub code.

You‚Äôll be taken to a GitHub page - just press ‚ÄúApprove & Install‚Äù!

Checkpoint

No command line here - you should be able to visit Travis, and see your name in the upper-right to indicate that you‚Äôre logged in.

Set Up ReadTheDocs

ReadTheDocs hosts your documentation, so that people know how to use your software! We‚Äôll get to ReadTheDocs nearer to the end of the tutorial, but let‚Äôs get things set up now.

Visit ReadTheDocs, and press Sign up, and the select Sign Up With GitHub. Like with Travis, you‚Äôll be asked to authorize ReadTheDocs to use your GitHub account ‚Äì do the same as you did before. ReadTheDocs will also ask you to confirm your email, so open up your email client and do so.

Checkpoint

No command line here either - you should be able to visit ReadTheDocs and see your GitHub username in the upper-right to indicate that you‚Äôre logged in.

Success!

We‚Äôve set up the various web services we‚Äôll need! Next is Part 3, where we‚Äôll get to the code!

A Note About The Internet

All of the services we‚Äôve go over are on the internet. There are local tools that can do the same sorts of things that out of the scope of this tutorial. If you need to keep you code secret, they might be right for you. In general, we recommend using web services like the above because they‚Äôre much less hassle to set up.
entry.summary: Welcome to Part 2! In this section we‚Äôll set up accounts for the web services that we need ‚Äì GitHub, Travis CI, and ReadTheDocs.

entry.title: Part 3: Getting the Code
entry.content:
Hello & welcome to Part 3! This is where we‚Äôll start to use the various things you‚Äôve installed to work with the code.

Get the Code

We‚Äôre going to go over some real-world basics of how git works and how conda works. We‚Äôll do this by getting you a copy of the code we‚Äôre going to work with on to your local machine, then installing the packages we need with conda.

Visit https://github.com/bmcfee/shablona, and press the Fork button. You‚Äôll be asked where to fork the code to ‚Äì select your own GitHub username. A ‚Äúfork‚Äù is your own copy of our code. You can change it without altering our code.

Now, visit https://github.com/<your-username>/shablona, and press the Clone button. Make sure to select Clone with SSH, and then copy the string that looks like git@github:<your-username>/shablona.git

Then, in your terminal, go to wherever you keep your code, and do git clone <that string>. This will do a lot of stuff! Once it is done, you should see a directory called shablona.

cd into that directory, then do ls. You should see the same files that you see on GitHub!

Checkpoint

From the shablona directory, run:

You should see:

Install Things with Conda

Conda, like we said earlier, is both a package manager and an environment manager. A package manager just installs things for you. An environment manager is a bit more complex ‚Äì it keeps track of different indepenent environments, each of which can have different things installed. So, for example, you can have one environment for this project and install the things that you need ‚Ä¶ and then have a different environment for a different project, with different packages installed!

This may sound like overkill, but it is very helpful in the long run. You‚Äôll often find that different projects have clashing requirements, and maintaining one environment per project will prevent this from getting out of hand.

So, let‚Äôs make one and install the code that we need! To create an environment for this tutorial, do conda create --name ismir-2018. You‚Äôll see that environment has been created at /Users/<your-user>/miniconda3/envs/ismir-2018-tutorial! Hooray! To turn it on do conda activate ismir-2018-tutorial.

This means that any Python code you install with conda or pip will only be installed in this environment. If you want to get out of this environment, just run source deactivate ‚Äì but don‚Äôt run it now!

For now, we‚Äôre going to install all the stuff we need. Run conda install --file requirements.txt. Lots of things should happen!

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see something like the below ‚Äì make sure that librosa is in list!

Run the Tests

So we‚Äôve installed all the packages we‚Äôll need. Let‚Äôs run the tests. Tests make sure that your code is doing what your think it is doing ‚Äì making sure that 2 + 2 in fact comes out to 4.

You can find the test code in the tests/ folder, and we‚Äôll talk more about testing later in the tutorial. For now, just run the tests with pytest.

üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí• OH NO EVERYTHING FAILED! üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•

Phew, ok, this is not actually a big deal at all. Failing tests are usually a good sign, becaue they mean that your tests found a bug or a problem. Let‚Äôs look at the error message that pytest is showing, and see if we can fix it.

Ah, this does not look so bad. We‚Äôre missing a package called pandas. We could just install it with conda, but we want to fix this problem for the long term. So, open up that requirements.txt file, and add the line pandas at the bottom, and the save it. Then re-run conda install --file requirements.txt, and then run the tests again.

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see:

Success!

We‚Äôve installed everything we‚Äôll need on our machines. In Part 2, we‚Äôll set up the various web apps and accounts that we‚Äôll need.
entry.summary: Hello & welcome to Part 3! This is where we‚Äôll start to use the various things you‚Äôve installed to work with the code.
